question: I beg your pardon? The Observer.
Sorry, sir.
answer: Hold on, Mark. Mark... I've a question for you. Which magazines sell the most copies?

question: Those with girls on the front covers - and no front covers on the girls.
answer: Exactly!... And it's just the same with the work you do for me. Look busy.

question: Exactly!... And it's just the same with the work you do for me. Look busy.
Certainly, sir.
Certainly, sir - anything else?
answer: I... er... have been told by a friend that you... er... have some views for sale?

question: What sort of views, sir?
This sort, sir?
Five shillings, sir.
answer: I'll take this one... and, er... this one... and, er... how much would the lot be?

question: To you - five pounds, sir... Tell you what, sir. Four pounds ten - and I'll throw in The Times and Telegraph... how's that?
answer: Well, er... thank you very much.

question: Let me wrap it for you, sir. Shall I put you on our mailing list?
answer: Oh no! But I'll look in again...

question: By all means, sir. He won't be doing the crossword tonight! Those pictures he chose... were all yours! This is yours! And this is yours too... And that's what I want to talk to you about. It's a clever picture - because you're a clever lad... but, Mark... It's all face. I don't want to hurt your feelings, son - but if people want the Mona Lisa they go to the National Gallery.
Well, wherever they go, they don't come here... so no more of this fancy stuff... ... now get upstairs - the girls are waiting... and so is a bonus if you give me what I want.
What do you do with all your money?
Buy cameras.
answer: Well look who's here! Cecil Beaton! Come on, sonny... make us famous. Did you read about that girl who was murdered last night? The same thing nearly happened to me! Last night! I went out with my boyfriend... We're getting married next month... trouble was my fiance saw us. can you fix it so the bruises don't show? Well, can you?

question: ...think so, Milly.
answer: Then be quick about it, sonny! I'm freezing. There he goes again! What have you got under there? A girlfriend? I suppose you have a girlfriend?

question: No, Milly.
Raise your head, please - and look at the sea.
I just wanted that puzzled look.
answer: Oh, did you? Well if you want it again, I'll think of you!

question: You're a puzzle and a half. This is a spare time job for you, isn't it?
Well, what do you do for a living?
This sort?
Don't you like this sort?
Well what sort do you like?
answer: I may show you - one day.

question: That'll be a treat, I'm sure.
Oh no, sonny! Now take one I can show my mother.

I'll ask him in... Excuse me! I don't know how many times we've passed each other on the stairs? ... but tonight I'm determined at least to say hello to you! So hello! I'm Helen Stephens. I'm having a party - and the other tenants are there... And a few friends. We'd like you to join us.
Pardon?
Hallo, Mark. Please come in... you'll meet the others who live here, and...
Thank you. Happy Birthday. ...minute...
answer: I hope I'm not disturbing you? I knew you wouldn't come down... so I've brought you this.

question: Thank you... ... very much...
answer: I mustn't keep you from your work

question: I'd like to offer you a drink.
I haven't one.
answer: I'd adore some water. a hostess can't drink water at her own party, it looks like a hint to the guests.

question: Will you... would you... like to come in?
There's milk... if you'd like some?
answer: Very much... if you can spare it?

question: Yes.
answer: Thank you, Mark... This is a pleasant room... and you've another inside?

question: Yes.
answer: How long have you lived here?

question: All my life. I was born in this house Oh? It's my father's.
answer: Do you mean I've at last found out who our landlord is? Your father?

question: Well - no... he's dead! I'm the landlord.
Yes.
answer: But you walk about as if you haven't paid the rent.

question: I haven't.
I know. It's his house - and I'll never sell it... but I can't afford the upkeep, so I let rooms. ... if I charge too much, tell me and I'll tell the agents.
answer: The rent's very reasonable, but don't say anything to the others or you'll have no peace.

question: Peace...?
Most of the time, I work in a film studio.
answer: On the photographic side, I'll bet.

question: I hope to be a film director... very soon.
I have some spare time jobs... as well.
More milk?
answer: No thank you... to do with photography?

question: Yes... to do with photography...
answer: When I came in were you looking at some films?

question: Yes.
Yes.
answer: I'd like to see them... Know I'm being rude... but I really would like to see them... ...it would be a birthday present... from you to me.

question: Would it?
Oh...
answer: But I suppose you're too busy?

question: Will you... would you... like to see them now?
I'll... go first.
answer: This is so... well - so many things... but above all - it's so... ...completely unexpected! Is all of it yours?

question: Yes.
answer: I mean... is it designed by you? Furnished by you? Tell me about this room.

question: It belonged to my father
Scientist...
No... Sold his to buy it...
answer: But it seems to be so... technical. If this is where you work, I can't wait to see what you work at.

question: Don't know what to show you?
answer: Well... what were you looking at when I interrupted you?

question: All right! This is the first... twenty-first birthday present... I'll ever have given.
answer: It's the first I've ever asked for... Mark, what a beautiful child. Who is he?

question: Me
answer: Of course it is! Then who took this film?

question: My Father.
answer: What a wonderful idea... You'll be able to show it to your own chi... You must have had a bad dream... ...but what was that light? ...The camera, I suppose? Whatever are you after? Naughty boy I hope you were spanked! ... but, Mark... what a strange thing for your father to photograph.

question: Switch off?
I hate people who chatter in films - but there's so much I want to ask. Again? Mark, this isn't some kind of jo...
Mark, whatever is that? What are you...
No, Mark! No! help me to understand this... this nightmare... All right... now look... Mark - what was all that about? ... that was a lizard, wasn't it? Or a...
Well how did it get there?... How did it get there Mark?... Was it a pet?
Won't you try to explain?
I like to understand what I'm shown! What was your father trying to do?... Photographing you at nigh...
Mark... what is this?
answer: I am saying... goodbye... my mother...

question: He... photographed... that...?
answer: Yes. ...and this! ...her funeral! ...and this! ...her burial! ...and this!

question: Mark, who is that?
Suc-?
answer: He married her... six weeks after... the previous sequence. She filmed... what comes now.

question: Is that your father?
answer: The morning that he left for his honeymoon.

question: What is he doing?
What was it?
Switch it off! Switch it off, Mark! So he was a scientist? What kind of scientist, Mark?
What was he trying to do to you? Mark!... What was he trying to do to you?
answer: Watch me... grow up... He wanted a record of a growing child... complete in every detail - if such a thing were possible - and he tried to make it possible by training a camera on me... at all times... I never knew... the whole of my childhood... one moment's privacy...

question: And those lights in your eyes?... and that - thing?
answer: He was interested ... in the reactions of the nervous system... to fear... Fear?

question: Fear?
Fear.
answer: We are looking at the spine of a book on Mark's shelf. The full title reads

question: Especially fear in children - and how they react to it.

I think he learned a lot... from me... I'd wake up... screaming... sometimes... and he'd be there... taking notes... and pictures... and I'm sure good came of it... for some people... He was brilliant.
answer: A scientist drops a lizard onto a child's bed - and good comes of it?

question: I don't know... if he did... but if he did... he'll have learned something of value...
answer: If only about lizards! Mark - it sounds to me as if your father was...

question: He founded clinics.
He was famous! Professor A. N. Lewis... three clinics.
answer: Why do you still live in his house... and watch his films?

question: They helped make me... what I am.
answer: A photographer? It's no wonder, is it? But you still haven't shown me anything you've photographed! Will you?

question: Mark?
Were you spotted?
Is it tonight?
Mark...
You're sure we won't be caught?
answer: Not if you do as I tell you.

question: I will, I promise.
answer: You haven't... said anything... to anyone?

question: Of course not.
Thank you. Mark... I want to be quite clear about this... Tonight, when the studio's empty... I'm to come back-and you're going to give me a film test... right?
You'll then print the film - so I can show it to my agent and anyone else who matters - right?
Mark... I've been offered film tests before... but I haven't liked the terms.
Then why are you doing this? Risking your job and...
answer: Not just for you... Viv... I have an agent too - and I want to show him what I can do... I want to direct...

question: There's someone coming.
answer: Hallo - lousy morning's work, wasn't it?

question: Yes.
answer: Thought I saw you talking to somebody...

question: I was learning my lines.
answer: Didn't know you had any... Want a drink? Dutch?

question: Later... perhaps.
Mark...
You didn't mind me asking?
No... you want to direct... more badly than anything don't you? Don't you, Mark?
answer: I want... to photograph... the impossible...

question: What is impossible?
answer: Something... that has never been photographed before.

question: What?
Very much, especially if there's a part for me.
answer: I want... to photograph a murder... while it's being committed.

question: No part for me then.
Is this a new script?
answer: I want... to frighten... someone... to death... and photograph... their expression of fear...

question: Mark! What's this story called?
answer: That is something... he never photographed...

question: Who? Who is he, Mark?
No one could... they'd be caught!
answer: I wouldn't care... if I had my picture.

question: Besides, how would you frighten anyone to death?
Well, what?
You'd better not tell me! I'll be scared to death tonight as it is! Back on the set - shall I go first?
What are you doing?
See you tonight!
...it's a wonderful subject, D.J.... Paramount wants it, M.G.M. wants it, Columbia wants it.
Danny Angel wants it!
answer: Are those budgets ready? Well bring 'em in.

question: Send me a memo - we'll discuss it next week.
answer: There's an error! The total should be a hundred and fifty thousand pounds fourteen shillings and sixpence - not thirteen and ninepence... That could mean the difference between profit and loss on a first feature!

question: There's an error! The total should be a hundred and fifty thousand pounds fourteen shillings and sixpence - not thirteen and ninepence... That could mean the difference between profit and loss on a first feature!
Any units working late tonight?
answer: Only one, sir. Night exteriors on the lot. The Elephant with two...

question: That animal needs a stick of dynamite! Remind me to pay them a visit tonight.
Catching the bus?
answer: Not tonight... meeting someone... for a drink.

question: Wanted to discuss the film at the Everyman... Tomorrow then?
Good night, Mark.
Mark...? Mark...? Mark...? Mark! Listen... we must... Where are you?
You frightened me! Now listen... they're working late on the lot.
answer: I know. They're branched off this stage - I'm using their juice.

question: We must call it off... someone's bound to see us.
answer: They might... ... but they won't interrupt us while we're filming... I've put the red light on.

question: You've what?...
Then they'll know someone's here.
They'll wait outside... what's the difference?
answer: The difference is... a perfect film... ... have waited... a long time... for this... and so have you ... no one... must interrupt it.

question: We'll be caught.
Matter!
answer: You stand to lose... a job as an extra... I stand to lose... nothing. ...the results must be so perfect... that the risks don't count... So perfect... that even he ... ... even he... would say...

question: Who Don Jarvis!? Oh! He'd say
answer: It's time to find out, Viv...

question: Come on! Get hot!
I do feel alone in front of it... I suppose stars never do?
answer: They feel alone without it... ... and the great ones... feel alone... all the time...

question: Then I'm great, boy! What is it you want me to act? Being frightened to death?
Yes - and I'll have a go! I've been wondering all the afternoon how you'd do it! I'll bet you've thought of a wonderful twist! What are you doing?
Why not pull the studio down while you're about it? They can only hang you once.
Be patient, Viv... it's going to be worth it.
answer: Oh well! I've stood alone in front of a studio camera! That's more than most have.

question: Ever stood... behind one?
Help yourself.
answer: I can see you, Mark... perfectly!

question: Good...
answer: Yes, sir! I'll bet I'm the best camerawoman in the business! . . . I've lost you!

question: I'll be back.
answer: Welcome, stranger! What are you doing?

question: Photographing you photographing me...
answer: Mark, you're brilliant... Lost you again!

question: Never mind. I'm ready now, Viv... Go and stand on that cross, will you?
Am I supposed to imagine someone is going to put me in there?
Mark - I hope I won't let you down... I know you're trying to create atmosphere for me - but... I just don't feel frightened! Wouldn't it be better if I just did my number?
Oh all right! I could do anything - I feel so relaxed - and that's due to you... You're so at home with that camera you make me feel at home too... you have it in you, boy!
answer: Ready, Viv? Well... Imagine someone... coming towards you... who's going to kill you - regardless of consequences...

question: A madman?
answer: Yes - but he knows it... and you don't... and just to kill you... isn't enough for him.

question: But how would he frighten me to?
answer: Stay there, Viv... you're... just right.

question: No thank you.
answer: What else can I read you?

question: The label on this whisky bottle! Are you sure it says seventy per cent proof?
They're bigger liars than the press!
I doubt it.
Don't haggle.
Done! Heads.
Huh. What are you looking at?
Wondering if that young man is home?
Well he is... I heard him come in... four paragraphs ago. Do you like him?
Why?
Wish this had.
answer: ... and I think he could help me.

question: With your photographs?
Helen...
It doesn't matter.
The price of whisky.
What else matters?
Haven't met him.
answer: You don't like him! Now why not?

question: I distrust a man who walks quietly.
His footsteps aren't! They're stealthy...
Are you going up to him?
We both have the key of the door... Mine needs oiling - and yours needs exercise... Off you go.
answer: Thank you. remember that you lost the toss.

question: Helen...
If you're back in five minutes... I won't even finish this.
Done!
Helen...
answer: Come in, Helen! Would you... please... wait in there?... Developing.

question: Mother heard you come in - so I guessed you wouldn't be in bed ... Are you sure this is conven...
Hallo, Mark... I hope you don't mind - is it a tape-recorder?
I'm sure I'm being a nuisance... but, Mark, I very much want to...
Mark! That's very sweet of you - but really.
answer: It isn't much... I don't know anything about... presents for twenty-one... but I saw it this morning... so... please.

question: Thank you... It's beautiful...
answer: I like the design... More milk?

question: More?... No, thank you, Mark... and I really appreciate this... I'm going to put it on now. There?... Or there?...
I think so too!... I am keeping you.
Mark, I'm here for some advice.
... I work in a public library - in the children's section... I'm telling you that to postpone admitting what always embarrasses me... In my spare time... I write.
I write stories for children... but so did Grimm... Hans Andersen... Lewis Carroll...
Some short stories.
I learned today... that my first book... has been accepted! ... For publication in the spring...
answer: But that's wonderful... what's it about?

question: A magic camera - and what it photographs...
answer: Whatever made you... think of that?

question: I'll tell you one day - I promise...

I'll tell you that too - but, Mark... this is the problem... The children who read the book will want to see the pictures the camera takes - but the publishers say they're impossible to photograph, and suggest drawings... but I don't agree.
was hoping you'd say that! There must be photographs - however difficult to take - and I was wondering, Mark - if you'd...
discuss it with me.
Mark - I can't ask you to do that... I mean... the publisher's mightn't agree.
Yes but... the money.
answer: There are some things... which I photograph... for nothing.

question: I didn't mean to offend you.
answer: Offend? Helen... if you knew what it meant... for something to happen to me... that I don't have to make happen... it's like... you've given me a twenty-first birthday... What does your camera photograph?

question: Mark - I must go... I just wanted to know... if you'd talk it over with me.
That's up to you.
answer: Helen ... I don't know much about... dinner out... but would you come with me?

question: Thank you.
When?
What's the matter?
Are you going away?
Oh... well you suggest when.
Yes.
I'll understand if you're not.
answer: I'll try to be - I'll try my hardest to be.

question: Thank you for listening... and for my present.
Good night, Mark...
Don't feel it! Do it!
Who?
Never mind - I'm cutting her out of this scene... Let's run it.
I'd like to see one in red.
... do you have one in white?
Do you have one in blue?
Mm? To collect your kid's autograph book? All right, Dawson - anything to help the Sergeant... ... and it's about time the Sergeant helped me - we're getting nowhere with this.
answer: What about that man the landlady passed?

question: She couldn't describe him - except to say that he was carrying something that she couldn't see.
Sergeant, I've been on the force thirty odd years... and I have never seen such fear on anyone's face as on this girl's... What was it she saw?
answer: Surely, Chief... a man coming at her - with a sharp weapon.

question: ...she said she didn't want a lift - because she had a call to make locally.
No, sir... and when I left, she was still in the dressing room.
answer: I see... let's have a look at this dressing room, shall we?

question: I've been watching you...
Have you been filming those policemen?
answer: Yes, I've a few quite interesting shots of them - it's a chance I never expected!

question: A chance for what?
answer: To photograph... an investigation... or as much of it as I can.

question: What on earth for?
answer: It will complete a documentary I'm making.

question: documentary? What's it about?
answer: I'd rather not tell you till it's finished. And it soon will be ...

question: But suppose they catch you?
answer: Oh they will - they look very efficient.

question: Don't you mind?
But they might confiscate your camera.
answer: I'm afraid they will! But by then... I'll have finished with it.

question: I don't...
Mark, hadn't you better leave that with me?
I'd look after it.
answer: I'm sure of that - but I'd like to photograph them while they're questioning me. I don't suppose they'll let me.

question: Mark, are you potty?
answer: Yes, do you think they'll notice?

question: Don't get into any trouble for heaven's sake  I want to discuss that film at the Everyman...
I've brought the camera in case you want to take the film away.
answer: That's all right, Mr. Lewis - as long as we don't appear at the Odeon next week in place of the cartoon.

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: Well now; have you anything to tell us?

question: Don't think so, sir.
Yes, sir...
Mainly by sight.
answer: When did you see her last?

question: Yesterday afternoon - when we broke...
Called out good night - don't know if she heard?
Took sqme shots, sir - for a film I'm making.
All over the place, sir... it's a documentary.
No, sir. Just my camera.
answer: What time did you arrive home, Mr. Lewis?

question: About ten... ten-thirty...
Yes... the people downstairs.
Right. That'll be all for the moment, Mr. Lewis - thank you.
Wait a minute. direct me to that set of yours, will you? I'd probably end on location.
I think I can find my way now... ...thanks for the escort
answer: No doubt at all... wounds were caused by the same instrument... ... both women... subjected to the most violent shock...

question: What sort of shock?

she was appearing in Arthur Baden's new film The Walls Are Closing In, starring Diane Ashley. a spokesman at the studio said that her performance in the film showed such promise, that her role was to have been built up... All work at the studio ceased today as a tribute to her memory!
answer: Mark is in films, isn't he?

question: Yes, darling... It is reliably...
answer: I wonder if he knew her?

question: I'll ask him tonight...
If he's free.
answer: That's very chivalrous of him. Where's he taking you?

question: I've no idea - and I don't suppose he has...
answer: Which studio does he work at?

question: I'll ask him.
I'll bring him in and introduce you if...
Now how can you?
answer: He's here. Why don't we make him a present of the window? He practically lives there!

question: How did you know where he was standing?
answer: The back of my neck told me... the part that I talk out of!

question: Hallo...
Yes.
I'd like you to come in for a moment - and meet my mother.
Darling, this is Mark... Mark, my mother.
answer: How do you do... Mrs. Stephens...

question: Darling, we forgot to toss. Supper's laid out in the kitchen.
answer: If you're not back early, you'll find me laid out with it!

question: We'll be early! Good night, darling.
Mark...
I want to ask you something rather personal... How long is it since you've gone out without that?
Your camera...
answer: Oh... I... don't think I know?

question: Exactly. I've never seen you without it... but are you going to need it tonight? Well are you? And if so... shall I bring some work with me too?
answer: I'm not going to need it tonight!

question: Good - then give it to me! ...It'll be quite safe - I'll put it away for you.
Then take it upstairs - if you can't trust me with it...
Then look... ...let's put it in here. Come in - and see for yourself. We'll put it in here - and lock it.
Was it, Mark?... I am being tactless, aren't I? ... It's just that... I thought it was growing into an extra limb, and - but you bring it with you if you want to. Thank you...
Thank you.
Yes?
answer: Can't describe it! Could only photograph it -

question: Shall I tell you what I feel?
Famished!
answer: Good! There's a small place round the corner... It's awfully good on Christmas Day.

question: Is it?
answer: Yes... there aren't too many open then.

question: No - it sounds fun.
I adore new restaurants... Where is this restaurant?
Sorry, young man, Helen's out.
With Mark - from upstairs.
You can stay and talk to me - if you like?
Know much about films?
Or film studios?
Where's Chipperfield Studios?
There's a phone book outside... Look up the number, will you? And see if you can get it.
answer: Certainly... and then I must go to my room.

question: I like this place! And this dinner! ...thank you, Mark...
answer: Are you ready to talk about your book?

question: I'm ready to talk about you... It won't take a second - and it's best to have it said. Carrying a camera is only one of your habits, isn't it, Mark? ... when you stared at that couple, you were like the little boy on that film you showed me... looking over the wall at something he shouldn't see. But Mark - you're strong enough now to lift that child off the wall... aren't you? ... aren't you?
Will you, Mark?... Will you really?
Lecture finished...
answer: When your book's published - will you go on working in a library?

question: Yes, Mark... in case, one day, a child comes in and asks for it!

I'm not popular with my customers! They ask me for horror comics - and I take their sticky hands and drag them to where there are books! ... and do you know, Mark, waiting for them to come in next time and ask for books... is as exciting... as a horror comic...
answer: What does your magic camera photograph?

question: People...

It's owned by a little boy who is terrified of grown-ups... but when he looks in his magic camera he sees grown-ups as they were when they were children... and he isn't frightened any longer. ... and one day he gives his camera away to a little boy who is even more frightened of grown-ups than he was - and do you know what he finds? ... that when he looks at grown- ups without his camera he can still see them as they were when they were children! And that means that he's grown up himself...
answer: What made you think of this story?

question: You did! ... I looked out of my window - and saw you going off to work carrying that camera like a little boy with a satchel... and an idea came... so thank you...
answer: I'd like to think... I was responsible... in some way...

question: Now what do I do about the photographs?
answer: Take 'em! Oh! There isn't a single face that doesn't look like a child's - not a single one - if you catch it at the right moment. It would be a challenge!... Unlike anything I've photographed!

question: What have you photographed, Mark?
answer: Everything. But nothing I'd want children to see. But this would belong to them - and they'd know if it wasn't right... Oh, Helen... I would like to find those faces for you... with you...

question: Very well! Let's try!
answer: You made a promise to your mother -

question: Yes, Mark...
Thank you... Mother must have gone to bed. Mark, it was a wonderful evening...
answer: That's what I was going to say... a wonderful evening...

question: And you made it wonderful... without your camera. I'll get it for you. wonder how this sees grown-ups? ...me, for instance... now that I am one.
Mark.
Why not?
Yes?
I don't understand. He'll wake Mother! ... thank you, again, for my evening. Will you go to bed now - and not stop up watching those films?
answer: Well... I've a little work to do... then I'll go to bed... and think of how to find faces for you... ...faces which - are faces which...

question: Good evening, Mark...
The young man bathing himself brought me to your door... I managed the rest of the adventure alone... This is one room I expected to find locked.
answer: I was never allowed a key..., can't get used to them. I brought her home early.

question: Thank you...
... a talk.
I'm at home here... I visit this room every night.
The blind always live in the rooms they live under... Every night you pace for hours above my head! Why?
answer: I've no one to talk to... in the rooms I live over...

question: I'm told that you stare too much... so do I. Cloth... with something hard inside it...
answer: It's a changing bag... we put films in it - so that the light won't spoil them...

question: How odd - that the light can spoil anything... Every night you switch on that film machine. What are these films you can't wait to look at?
What is the film you're showing now? Why don't you lie to me? I'd never know...
Take me to your cinema.
What am I seeing, Mark? Why don't you answer?
answer: It's no good - I was afraid it wouldn't be.

question: What?
They always do.
I've yet to meet an artist who could judge his own work... What do you think you've spoiled?
answer: An opportunity... now I must find another.

question: Why are you putting those lights on my face? Mark...
answer: It's almost over... Please let me finish! It's for Helen!

question: What do you mean? It's for Helen?
answer: She wants to see something I've photographed!

question: My daughter sees enough of my face without photographs...
Not frightened! Hot! So put that camera away...
In rather a hurry, aren't you?
answer: It's late. You must be tired...

question: You're anxious to get rid of me all of a sudden. I won't be selfish... You can take some more pictures - if you want to...
Why not, Mark?

Can't you find some - to please Helen? You don't trust yourself to take any more, do you? Instinct's a wonderful thing, isn't it Mark? A pity it can't be photographed. if I'd listened to it years ago, I might have kept my sight. I wouldn't have let a man operate I had no faith in... so I'm listening to it now... It says all this filming isn't healthy - and that you need help... ... get it, Mark... get it quickly... and until you've got it... I don't want you and Helen to see each...
answer: I'll never photograph her... I promise you that.

question: I'd rather you don't have the chance. I mean it, Mark. And if you don't listen to me... one of us will move from this house - which would be a pity, because we'd never find a cheaper...
answer: You'll never have to move... because of me... I promise you.

question: Good boy. The stairs are the difficult part... Far enough, Mark...
Yes ...
answer: It's been a long time... since anyone did...

question: Mark... what's troubling you?
No... I'll be frank. I'd welcome anyone's help... I don't know how this maniac kills - or why he kills - or who he'll kill next, but if he isn't caught quickly...
answer: Inspector, have you convinced yourself he's a member of my unit?

question: No, sir ... but a few things seem to point to it... No one outside your unit admits to knowing the girl... There was a trunk all ready for her... and with the risks he was running, I think he'd have to use surroundings he was familiar with... Where is your unit now?
answer: Waiting for me on the set.

question: I'd like to watch them at their jobs, sir. It may tell me more than a hundred interviews.
answer: But, Inspector, the strain on them is already...

question: Ten minutes break, everyone! Can you suggest anything, Doctor?
answer: No. It looked jolly interesting to me.

question: I mean to help her psychologically...
answer: Yes. Give the girl a proper rest... Ten minutes is useless!

question: Thank you, Doctor.
What's your job?
Oh... so am I, in a way.
answer: I was wondering if you knew my father - Professor Lewis...

question: Professor... but of course I knew him. He lectured to me. He was an extraordinary man - quite brilliant!
answer: You know what he was interested in before he died?

question: No? Tell me...
answer: I don't remember what he called it... It was something to do with what causes people to be... peeping Toms...

question: Scoptophilia!... That would interest him! A most fertile mind.
philia... The morbid urge to gaze... Coined since his day... Have you any manuscripts of his which I could...?
answer: He thought... it could be cured...

question: Usually. Now about his manuscripts -
The cure? Very quick... A couple of years analysis - three times a week - an hour a time - and it's soon up-rooted... ... if you've any of his papers on the subject?
Can't wait to show you this! I ought to charge you! You don't get that in Sight and Sound - Isn't she terrific? Got some more - if you're interested?
I'll bet I have! Hey! Where are you going?
answer: Phone - may be my last chance - and... thanks.

question: But your lunch?
... some photograph! Well lit too!
answer: Can't manage Saturday, sir, but they're letting us off early today! This afternoon - after work - may be my last chance!

question: Can't manage Saturday, sir, but they're letting us off early today! This afternoon - after work - may be my last chance!
answer: ... be here at six o'clock. Milly'll be waiting.

question: Six o'clock...
answer: On the dot, Mark, or she'll go.

question: I'll be there, sir.
Is that all he wanted?
answer: think so... we had a little chat about scoptophilia - and he's going to show me...

question: About what?
Eh?
answer: What makes people into Peeping Toms, one of his father's subjects, apparently.

question: Peeping Toms...
answer: An interesting boy... he has his father's eyes... you don't suspect him, do you?

question: I suspect 'em all - what about you?
answer: I'm interested in that chap with the bald head and hatchet face... there's something on his mind!

question: Got your list, Sergeant?
I want to see how some of them spend their spare time...
Don't make a habit of this!
Milly's upstairs.
You've spoiled my whole evening, you have!
What's the idea?
Why? Going on manoeuvres with the boy scouts?
Have you gone absolutely...
Darling... Darling.
Hallo, Tony...
To leave something for Mark...
answer: You haven't much time for me these days.

question: Tony...
answer: It's all right - I'll be here - if you want me. ... by the way... your mother was yelling out something before you came in... about Mark photographing her.

question: Photographing Mother? You must be mistaken!
Don't let me see you... frightened... Leave! Hurry, Helen!
Leave!
Now!
answer: That film... That film... ... is ... just a film... ... isn't it? ... horrible ... horrible... but... just a film... isn't it?

question: No... I killed them... And now that you know... I want you with me... a while. You'll be safe - as long as I can't see you frightened - so stand in the shadows, Helen... please... ... please...
answer: She's right... your mother... must tell someone everything... sorry... has to be you! This was his laboratory... and you know some of what he did... but not all.

question: Turn it off! Look at me, Mark!
Look at me! What did you do... to those girls?
What did you do, Mark...? If you want to torment me... for the rest of my life... then make me imagine! What did you do ... to those girls?
Show me, Mark...
Show me - or I'll remain frightened... for the rest of my life. Show me!
answer: Do you know... what the most frightening thing in the world is?... It's fear. So I did something... very simple... Very simple. When they felt the spike... touching their throats... and knew I was going to kill them... ... I made them - watch their own deaths! Made them see their own terror as the spike went in... and if death has a face, they saw that too! Not you! Not you! I'll never photograph you! I promised - I promised - Not you!
